newsitem.title: BELGIUM: OLO CURVE FLATTENING SEEN WITH LIMITED ROOM TO RUN.
newsitem.headline: OLO CURVE FLATTENING SEEN WITH LIMITED ROOM TO RUN.

text.p: A flattening move that compressed the Belgian linear bond yield curve by about four basis points on Thursday was likely to continue on Friday, dealers said.
But dealers saw little chance the move turning into an extended rout of shorter maturities. "It could go another one or two basis points, but I don't believe it will do much more," one trader said.
The short end of the Belgian yield curve continued to suffer in line with Germany on Thursday in the wake of interest rate comments by Bundesbank chief economist Otmar Issing.
Issing said on Wednesday a further rate easing was not to be expected nor necessary.
Provisional data on Thursday showing West German inflation in October rose to 1.5 percent from 1.4 percent in September also put pressure on shorter maturities, one trader said.
He said, however, that investors were merely moving their money along the yield curve and not switching out of Belgium.
"Five and six year paper was well offered all day...but OLO 12s and 23s were very well bid," he said, referring to the eight percent bonds maturing in December 2012 and 2015.
